lead_paragraph: The convoy attack and resumed bombings were the strongest signs yet of the unraveling of an agreement between Russia and the United States aimed at restarting peace talks to end the conflict in Syria.

byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Michael R. Gordon from New York. Reporting was contributed by Somini Sengupta from the United Nations, Ben Hubbard from Beirut, Andrew Higgins from Moscow, Maher Samaan from Paris, Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva, Helene Cooper from Washington, and Rick Gladstone from New York.
byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and MICHAEL R. GORDON

headline.print_headline: Aid Convoy Is Hit in Syria as Cease-Fire Falters and Bombings Resume
headline.main: Aid Convoy Is Hit in Syria as Cease-Fire Falters and Bombings Resume

snippet: The convoy attack and resumed bombings were the strongest signs yet of the unraveling of an agreement between Russia and the United States aimed at restarting peace talks to end the conflict in Syria....
abstract: Attack on humanitarian aid convoy in Aleppo, Syria, exacerbates tensions and threatens broader peace agreement made between Russia and United States; attack follows, within minutes, end of temporary partial cease-fire that was intended to assist civilians trapped in war-ravaged city.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
